body: I've provided a PR with four failing unit tests: #1716

Indeed the behavior comes from the fact that doubles are compared according to https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Double.html#compareTo(java.lang.Double) which:

> Compares two Double objects numerically. There are two ways in which comparisons performed by this method differ from those performed by the Java language numerical comparison operators (<, <=, ==, >=, >) when applied to primitive double values:
> -   Double.NaN is considered by this method to be equal to itself and greater than all other double values (including Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY).
> -   0.0d is considered by this method to be greater than -0.0d.  

I think it is fair in that case to follow equals behavior and consider 0.0d to be equal to -0.0d,  to follow the behavior less surprising for most users.

Users who want to use the `compareTo` semantics can use `isEqualByComparingTo`.

We will check the behavior for other primitive types and make similar adjustment ( I think it only concerns double and float).
Thanks @joel-costigliola! jls-5.6.2 may be relevant here as well, depending how we go about implementing the solution https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se11/html/jls-5.html#jls-5.6.2

My root cause analysis is actually not complete, AssertJ only uses `compareTo` for `isGreaterThanOrEqualTo` but uses [`Double.equals`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Double.html#equals(java.lang.Object)) for `isEqualTo` which states:

> If d1 represents +0.0 while d2 represents -0.0, or vice versa, the equal test has the value false, even though +0.0==-0.0 has the value true. 

AssertJ usually follows the core java classes behavior so that would mean `isEqualTo`  would follow this behavior:
* if given a `Double`: delegates to `Double.equals` and fails
* if given a `double`: uses use `==` and pass

For consistency `isGreaterThanOrEqualTo` should follow the same behavior and evaluate `isEqualTo` before `isGreaterThan`.

@carterkozak WDYT?
That sounds reasonable to me, thanks!

issue.title: Float and Double isNotEqualTo should use primitive comparison when compared to primitive float/double values

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary

`assertThat(Double.NaN).isNotEqualTo(Double.NaN)`  fails when it should pass as `Double.NaN==Double.NaN` has the value false (as per https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Double.html#equals(java.lang.Object).  

The reason is succeeds is that `isNotEqualTo` converts `Double.NaN` to a `Double` and uses  `Double.equals` instead `==`.

This should have been changed as part of https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/issues/1715.

issue.title: assertThat(Double.NaN).isEqualTo(Double.NaN) fails

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary
`assertThat(Double.NaN).isEqualTo(Double.NaN);` fails with 

```
[ERROR] Failures: 
[ERROR]   Doubles_assertEqual_Test.should_pass_if_doubles_are_NaN 
Expecting:
 <"NaN (Double@691505cf)">
to be equal to:
 <"NaN (Double@79f3359e)">
but was not.
```

#### Example

```java
  @Test
  public void should_pass_if_doubles_are_NaN() {
    assertThat(Double.NaN).isEqualTo(Double.NaN);
  }
```

It seems like this is related to https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/issues/1715 ? but it still fails on master if I add the above test to src/test/java/org/assertj/core/internal/doubles/Doubles_assertEqual_Test.java

I tried `doubles.assertEqual(someInfo(), Double.NaN, Double.NaN);` also and that still works
